subsections.title: Big Sky Overview
highlights: Resort town located between Bozeman and West Yellowstone
Home to Big Sky Resort and scenic Lone Mountain
Outdoor paradise year-round: skiing, hiking, rafting, and concerts

subsections.title: Skiing & Snowboarding
highlights: Big Sky Resort – over 5,800 acres of terrain
Known for Lone Peak Tram and expert bowls
Lift tickets: $175–$240/day (variable by season)
Ikon Pass accepted, with limited days

subsections.title: Summer Activities & Hiking
highlights: Beehive Basin Trail – wildflowers and Lone Peak views
Ousel Falls Trail – family-friendly hike to waterfall
Mountain biking and ziplining at the resort
Fly fishing on the Gallatin River

subsections.title: Dining & Breweries
highlights: Horn & Cantle – upscale rustic at Lone Mountain Ranch
Blue Buddha Sushi Lounge – fresh, modern rolls
Lone Peak Brewery – casual spot for local brews
Ousel & Spur Pizza Co – cozy Italian with views

subsections.title: Lodging & Vacation Rentals
highlights: Summit Hotel – ski-in/ski-out luxury
Huntley Lodge – classic resort hotel
Cowboy Heaven Cabins – rustic mountain retreats
Airbnbs and private condos available in Meadow Village

subsections.title: Festivals & Local Events
highlights: Big Sky Farmers Market – Wednesdays in summer
Music in the Mountains – free summer concert series
Big Sky PBR (Professional Bull Riding) – July rodeo weekend
Winter events: pond skim, ski races, and après ski parties

subsections.title: Shopping & Town Center
highlights: Big Sky Town Center – dining, retail, markets
Independent outdoor gear shops and boutiques
Art galleries and gift shops with Montana-made goods

subsections.title: Nearby Day Trips
highlights: Yellowstone National Park – 1 hour south
Bozeman – 1 hour north for airport and museums
Gallatin Canyon scenic drive – river and wildlife
Lone Mountain Ranch sleigh ride dinners (winter)

subsections.title: Campgrounds & Outdoor Access
highlights: Red Cliff Campground – along Gallatin River
Greek Creek Campground – forested with hiking access
Taylor Fork area – dispersed camping and wildlife
Backcountry trails into Lee Metcalf Wilderness

subsections.title: Loop Integration & Travel Tips
highlights: Best visited in July–September or January–March
Part of scenic route: Bozeman → Big Sky → West Yellowstone
Can be paired with Ennis or Gallatin Gateway for rustic retreats
Expect variable cell service in canyons and some trailheads
